title: From Gaming to Research: GTA V for Synthetic Data Generation for Robotics and Navigations
author: Matteo Scucchia (University of Bologna), Matteo Ferrara (University of Bologna), Davide Maltoni (University of Bologna), ...
relevance_why: This paper explores synthetic data generation using a gaming environment, which could provide novel methods for dataset curation in the audio domain, particularly for tasks like audio analysis under varying conditions.
background: The research focuses on using synthetic data from the video game Grand Theft Auto V for computer vision tasks relevant to robotics and navigation.
contribution: This paper introduces a synthetic dataset for SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) and VPR (Visual Place Recognition) tasks using data from Grand Theft Auto V, demonstrating its qualitative comparability to real-world data.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on real-world datasets, making them expensive and time-consuming to collect.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages a controlled gaming environment to create diverse synthetic datasets efficiently, offering the ability to generate extensive data without real-world constraints.

key_innovation: The use of a gaming platform to automate data collection under various simulated conditions, enhancing the variety and volume of datasets available for machine learning tasks.
real_world_impact: This approach can significantly reduce the time and cost associated with data collection in robotics, fostering innovations in autonomous navigation and localization systems.
limitations: The authors do not discuss the potential loss in realism when transferring findings from a simulated environment to real-world applications.

new_terms.Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (S: **Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM)** is a technique used by robots to build a map of an unknown environment while keeping track of their own location within it.
new_terms.Visual Place Recognition (VPR): **Visual Place Recognition (VPR)** involves identifying a location based on visual information, crucial for tasks like robot navigation and understanding the environment.

open_sourcing: Code and data will be released at https://github.com/scumatteo/GTA-rn upon acceptance.
